It is highly unlikely that Assad would not be president of Syria before 1 January 2019. The US and other countries that condemn Assad also do not want to be pulled further into the civil war to take down Assad as their troops would certainly suffer casualties and there is not enough support at home to rationalize this. Also, they don't want more powerful weapons to  end up in the hands of groups like ISIL, so they only send less powerful weapons to support the rebels, meaning that there is less chance of the rebels ousting Assad forcefully.

In addition, the opposition doesn't seem to have an idea of who who should replace Bashar al-Assad. Therefore it is very unlikely that the Bashar al-Assad will cease to be president of Syria within such a short timeframe.

President Assad's family has been in power for over a quarter of a century, and during his presidency he has shown how he wants to continue to have that power through explicit force, corruption, and human rights abuses. Although it is clear that many Syrian citizens despise him, outside actors such as Russia and Iran have elevated his power and prevented a change in government despite a clear need to relinquish his power. These outside actors, especially Russia have a lot of power on the international stage, and because the U.S. is focused on their own national security rather than the sovereignty of Syria, they are not likely to directly focus their efforts on addressing the situation before January, unless Assad poses a direct threat to the United States.

The Assad Regime is embroiled in a civil war with U.S.-backed Syrian opposition forces. Though embattled, Assad has been able to maintain his grip on power because of strong support from allies such as Russia and Iran. The U.S. has remained committed to supporting the opposition even after significant gains towards a key objective, the destruction of ISIS. The dismantling of ISIS has effectively provided a more stable operating environment for Assad. Each side in the Syria conflict, Assad and the opposition, will continue to be propped up by Russia and the U.S. respectively. Russia underwrites Assad's power in Syria providing the funds, equipment, and military advisor to the Syrian Army. Russia nor Iran is willing to endure the projection of weakness that would follow should they concede to U.S. pressure. There are also reports of Assad maintaining authority over billions in humanitarian assistance received from UN OCHA. If accurate, this certainly provides Assad additional buoyancy to withstand pressure attempts to remove him from power.
Barring a random accident or bad luck, Assad looks very likely to survive as President into next year.

Bashar al-Assad has managed to retain his position as leader of Syria after nearly six years of war. Assad is likely to remain the leader in Syria for the forseeable future for several  reasons. One of the most important reasons is the weakening of his opposition and enemies. The Free Syrian Army is no longer as intimidating as it once was at the beginning of the conflict and the opposition in the country has virtually disappeared. If Assad is to be replaced, there needs to be a new figure that not only enjoys broad support, but would even be allowed to run. Assad has taken steps to solidify his power over the years and he has enjoyed support from Russia, Hezbollah, and Iran, which are powerful actions in the region. Russia has become very entangled in the war as well and is determined to keep Assad in power. Due to their influence, it is likely that any negotiations on Syria's future will involve them. If the US and its allies were to intervene in Syria, it is likely this would bring a conflict with Russia, which is not in the interests of the United States. Assad has also made progress on retaining and expanding his territory in Syria and with continued Russian help, his opposition is likely to be defeated. Without US intervention and a viable opposition in Syria, change is unlikely. Therefore, Assad is likely to remain in power for the foreseeable future.

Leading up to the Syrian Civil War, Syria had already been an ally of Iran since the 80's, in part to enable the Hezbollah political presence in Lebanon. The toppling of Saddam's secular Sunni dictatorship over Shia majority Iraq by the US opened up a completed Shia Crescent aligned with Iran, after the 2011 US withdrawal. IS emerged as a coherent territorial actor in the Middle East because its emergence split the Shia Crescent, a goal that worked inadvertently toward the interests of Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Israel, and the US. Now that this reality is gone, the objective becomes for the aforementioned powers to see if they can cleave the Alawite-dominated coast of Syria off of the rest of the Shia Crescent, so as to contain Iran. The US will guarantee that this occurs at some point through a regime change campaign, but this will require a UN-sanctioned multilateral intervention by the aforementioned powers, the US, maybe Russia and some others. This isn't going to happen in 2018, but Assad might be ousted with Iran's acquiescence as a placating measure to the international community.

Syria has had a long and storied past with its ruling party. Most notably Bashar al-Assad assumed power after his father's death in 2000. Bashar's father ruled Syria from 1971 through 2000. The family has infiltrated the government for a very longtime and rules with an iron fist. Although the countries constitutions reads like a democracy, it is run like a police state. A police state that has been run by the same family for decades. Bashar, like his father, uses secret police and military action to maintain dominance throughout the country. The question becomes, who will remove Bashar al-Assad from power? Currently, ISIS was a grave threat to Syria, but with the global effort to eliminate ISIS, it appears that their stronghold in the region has all but evaporated. The other factions within Syria that oppose al-Assad's government are being suppressed by pro-Syrian Russian forces that bring strong military backing. And recently Rex Tillerson has indicated, along with Trump, that Assad is no longer a threat that is a top priority to the US and that the Syrian people control Assad's fate. Understanding that the power Assad holds over the Syrian government, it is hard to fathom that the Syrian people have much control over Assad's fate and will over throw the dictator. A coalition of actors that could push Assad out has not emerged.  Iran has been a big winner in the region over time and Russia has an interest in preserving Assad in power. These actors are proximate and have influence in the region. Turkey appears to be cooperating with Russia for the time being and preserving Assad in power may be part of this enhanced cooperation.  Israel may view Assad as a known devil and be unwilling to support actors that could throw him out of power. Similarly, the United States may be hesitant to push Assad out.  Outside factors are unlikely to dislodge Assad and inside factors are likely to seek stability by supporting existing leadership unless getting rid of the leader promises greater security. Since force appears to be an essential component of leading in the Middle East, Assad is unlikely to be removed as long as he is willing to wield force and maintain alliances with Russia and Iran. Of course unknown factors can always lead to a shift in the internal or external power calculus.

Based on the current base rate, it seems highly unlikely that al-Assad will no longer be president of Syria by January 1, 2019. He has survived, uproar, unrest, civil war and the whims and wills of the Russians as well as any number of other players. His best attribute is his sheer stubbornness and unwillingness to upset any of his "friends" or shall we call them "frenemies" to the point of taking extreme action against him, thus allowing him to remain in the palace and endure. But, there is NEVER a 100% certainty of an outcome, so I have to give a 3% probability that something completely unexpected or unanticipated could happen to have him cease to be president...slip on soap in the shower, stray bullet (there is fighting going on in places!), chokes on a apricot pit...I think you get my drift. Following my line of thinking, you would notice that none of these examples have him being forcibly removed from power. The 3% does accommodate the unlikely event of this occurring.

Having survived the civil war, and having the backing of the Russian government, I see no reason to believe that he will either surrender power or be removed from power during the timeframe given.
